lines.text: Enter KING LEAR, KENT, and Fool

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Go you before to Gloucester with these letters. Acquaint my daughter no further with any thing you know than comes from her demand out of the letter. If your diligence be not speedy, I shall be there afore you.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered your letter.
Exit

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: If a man's brains were in's heels, were't not in danger of kibes?

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Ay, boy.

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Then, I prithee, be merry; thy wit shall ne'er go slip-shod.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Ha, ha, ha!

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly; for though she's as like this as a crab's like an apple, yet I can tell what I can tell.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Why, what canst thou tell, my boy?

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: She will taste as like this as a crab does to a crab. Thou canst tell why one's nose stands i' the middle on's face?

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Why, to keep one's eyes of either side's nose; that what a man cannot smell out, he may spy into.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: I did her wrong--

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell?

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Nor I neither; but I can tell why a snail has a house.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Why, to put his head in; not to give it away to his daughters, and leave his horns without a case.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: I will forget my nature. So kind a father! Be my horses ready?

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Thy asses are gone about 'em. The reason why the seven stars are no more than seven is a pretty reason.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Because they are not eight?

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Yes, indeed: thou wouldst make a good fool.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: To take 't again perforce! Monster ingratitude!

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I'ld have thee beaten for being old before thy time.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: How's that?

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven Keep me in temper: I would not be mad! How now! are the horses ready?
Enter Gentleman

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: Ready, my lord.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Come, boy.

lines.speaker: fool
lines.text: She that's a maid now, and laughs at my departure, Shall not be a maid long, unless things be cut shorter.
Exeunt
